body: Successfully reproduced on Windows 10 with 342.01 running a G 105M. Unable to reproduce with 385.41 (same driver version as OP) on Windows 7.

Can confirm that if app runs with vsync on and is switched to fullscreen with `glfwSetWindowMonitor(window, glfwGetPrimaryMonitor(), 0, 0, width, height, GLFW_DONT_CARE);` vsync gets seemingly disabled. I assumed that this was because of the `GLFW_DONT_CARE` and now always manually call another `glfwSwapInterval` after switching to fullscreen - which is fine right?

Windows 10 Pro 64-bit, GTX 760 and 388.13 NVIDIA drivers which are even newer.

@elmindreda you probably know this but I think it comes from WGL swap interval not being used when desktop composition is enabled: `HACK: Disable WGL swap interval when desktop composition is enabled to avoid interfering with DWM vsync`. So when switching to fullscreen, DWM vsync stops being used, but WGL swap interval is still disabled.

I'd gladly do a pull request if given instructions but I'm pretty sure you know way better how to fix it. Just wanted to share what I found in case it helps!

I can still reproduce this reliably on Windows 10 Home 64bit 10.0.18363 with 441.66 NVIDIA drivers on a GTX 1070 with GLFW built from master. However, the mentioned workaround does not work for me. I'd love to see this get fixed so if there is anything I could do to find the cause please let me know.

I can also reproduce this reliably on Windows 10 Pro 64bit 10.0.18362.476 running 441.66 NVIDIA drivers on a RTX 2080. The mentioned workaround works for me but only after changing the VSync option inside the NVIDIA control panel from "Off" back to "Use the 3D application setting". My guess is that the NVIDIA driver ignores the call to wglSwapIntervalEXT if the VSync option is set to "Off" inside the control panel.

issue.title: Fixes #5826.
issue.body:
As described in #5826 and confirmed by testing, on Windows the vsync setting is ignored if fullscreen mode is enabled. Setting the vsync mode again fixes this.

This is a more concise version of #6150, that also supports multi-window setups.

May be caused by https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/1072.

body:
@elmindreda Is this fix in 3.3.7? I just tried with my game and this still happens.

I am particularly concerned because the `DwmFlush()` "hack" is still necessary even on Windows 8 and greater. I have been looking into this recently because SDL2 doesn't do this, and I can *very* much confirm to you that `DwmFlush()` is still necessary on modern Windows. See https://github.com/libsdl-org/SDL/issues/5797

@PJB3005 That is very useful to know, thank you! I don't have a Windows 8 machine to test on and I wasn't able to reproduce it on any Windows 10 machine. There were DXGI upgrades in Windows 10 that seemed related to this, so I assumed it couldn't happen there.

Do you have Windows 8 or 10 machines where it happens and would you be willing to help improve this hack? If it does occur on Windows 10, it should possibly also have a platform-specific window hint.
I'm on Windows 11 though I admit I can't exactly test Windows 10 or earlier directly.
